item.title: Rhombus with Tor
item.description: a) Using the Tor Browser b) Using the Tor Daemon c) Tor as a Hidden Service The only privacy protocol that’s not enabled by default on Rhombus Desktop is the ability to hide your IP address using the Tor network. While it could eventually be enabled by default or through the Settings page, Tor currently needs to be activated manually to route your Rhombus Desktop connection through its network.

item.title: Running multiple wallets
item.description: Multiwallet setup Rhombus Core Autostart multiwallet Rhombus Desktop Rhombus Core Linux You might want to create and use multiple wallets for different usage. The goal is to separate your finances, so they won’t mix up. This approach will also help you gain a bit more privacy (never linking all of your available funds).

item.title: Self-hosting RHOM payment processor
item.description: By hosting your own instance of Rhombus’s BTCPayServer, you can create your very own independent payment processor for both Rhombus and Bitcoin. About BTCPayServer Features Available servers Installation Requirements Generate docker-compose.yml Run BTCPayServer About BTCPayServer Features See official BTCPayServer website for complete info about features and abilities. To name a few: No fees – no processing/transaction fees or any 3rd-party eating up your profits Peer to peer – coins are sent directly from buyer to seller, they don’t sit on the server itself (no middleman) Multiple coins supported – BTC (with optional Lightning), RHOM, LTC and more… No KYC – keep your identity to yourself Self-hosted – you’re in control Available servers Following BTCPayServer servers are run by the community and open for public, in case you don’t want/need to run your own:

item.title: Rhombus as Tor Hidden Service
item.description: Download Rhombus wallet Install Tor Define HS in Tor config Find your IP for HS Modify rhombus.conf Start wallet It also protects your machine from geolocation and its possible ugly consequences, and automatically sets you up for both incoming and outgoing connections, helping the Rhombus network. It is recommended to always run the Rhombus through Tor. This guide is written purely for Linux (specificaly Ubuntu-based distributions).

item.title: Tips for increasing privacy
item.description: Basics Rhombus Transactions Balances Network Other resources Here are a few tips to keep you private as much as possible: Basics Never brag about how much RHOM or BTC you own, online or offline. All it does is bringing attention to you; scammers and hackers would surely love to get a piece of your pie. It’s not worth the risk.
